Sales_Normal: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = %s ORDER BY order_date DESC LIMIT 5
SELECT /* check */ o.* , c.name AS customer_name FROM orders o JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id WHERE c.id = %s ORDER BY o.order_date DESC LIMIT 5
SELECT * FROM orders WHERE id IN (SELECT customer_id FROM customers WHERE email = %s ORDER BY created_at DESC LIMIT 5)
SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = ( SELECT id FROM customers WHERE name = %s ORDER BY created_at DESC LIMIT 1 )
SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = ( SELECT id FROM customers WHERE email LIKE %s ORDER BY created_at DESC LIMIT 1 )
SELECT * FROM customers WHERE email = %s
SELECT id, name FROM customers WHERE email = 'example@example.com'
SELECT * FROM customers c INNER JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id WHERE c.email = %s AND o.order_date IN (SELECT order_date FROM orders GROUP BY order_date ORDER BY order_date ASC LIMIT 1, 1)
SELECT id FROM customers /* using a subquery */
SELECT * FROM products WHERE sku = %s
SELECT id, name, price FROM products WHERE sku = %s
SELECT * FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id JOIN order_items oi ON o.id = oi.order_id WHERE oi.sku = %s
SELECT p.* FROM products p LEFT JOIN order_items oi ON p.sku = oi.sku WHERE oi.sku = %s
SELECT name, price FROM products p WHERE sku = %s LIMIT 1
UPDATE orders SET status = 'Shipped' WHERE id = %s
UPDATE customers c JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id, UPDATE orders SET status = 'Shipped' WHERE id = %s
SELECT * FROM orders SET status = 'Shipped' WHERE id = %s
UPDATE orders JOIN customers ON customers.id = orders.customer_id SET status = 'Shipped' WHERE id = %s
UPDATE orders o INNER JOIN customers c ON c.id = o.customer_id SET status = 'Shipped' WHERE o.id = %s
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM orders WHERE status = 'Completed'
SELECT * FROM orders WHERE STATUS='COMPLETED'
SELECT id, customer_id FROM orders GROUP BY id HAVING status = 'Completed'
SELECT count(id) FROM orders WHERE status = 'COMPLETEd'
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM orders
SELECT * FROM orders
HR_Normal: SELECT name, position FROM employees INNER JOIN salaries ON employees.id = salaries.employee_id WHERE salaries.employee_id = %s
SELECT s.* FROM salaries s INNER JOIN employees e ON s.employee_id = e.id WHERE s.employee_id = %s
SELECT * FROM salaries s LEFT JOIN employees e ON e.id = s.employee_id WHERE s.employee_id = %s
SELECT s.salary FROM salaries s INNER JOIN employees e ON s.employee_id = e.id WHERE e.id = %s AND s.to_date IS NULL ORDER BY s.from_date
SELECT * FROM salaries s INNER JOIN employees e ON s.employee_id = e.id WHERE e.id = %s AND s.to_date IS NULL
SELECT salary FROM salaries WHERE employee_id = %s AND to_date IS NULL AND from_date = ( SELECT MAX(from_date) FROM salaries WHERE employee_id = %s )
SELECT s2.salary FROM salaries s2 JOIN (SELECT id FROM employees WHERE name LIKE '%s') e ON s2.employee_id = e.id WHERE s2.to_date IS NULL ORDER BY s2.from_date
SELECT e.id, e.name FROM employees e JOIN departments d ON e.position = d.name WHERE d.department_name = 'Engineering'
SELECT id, name FROM employees WHERE position=%s
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE hire_date IN (SELECT employee_id FROM salaries s JOIN departments d ON s.from_date = d.hire_date WHERE department_name = 'Engineering')

SELECT id 
FROM employees e 
JOIN positions p ON e.position = p.position 
JOIN departments d ON p.department = d.department_name 
WHERE d.department_name = 'Engineering'
SELECT id, name FROM employees e JOIN (SELECT employee_id, from_date, to_date FROM salaries) s ON e.id = s.employee_id WHERE e.position = 'Software Engineer'
SELECT COUNT(e.id) FROM employees e JOIN salaries s ON e.id = s.employee_id WHERE s.from_date >= CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR AND s.to_date IS NULL
SELECT * FROM employees e JOIN salaries s ON e.id = s.employee_id WHERE s.from_date >= (CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR)
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM employees e LEFT JOIN salaries s ON e.id = s.employee_id AND s.from_date <= (CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR) AND (s.to_date IS NULL OR s.to_date >= (CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR))

SELECT * FROM employees WHERE id IN ( SELECT employee_id FROM salaries s JOIN (SELECT hire_date, hire_date + INTERVAL 1 YEAR) AS t ON s.from_date >= t.hire_date AND (s.to_date IS NULL OR s.to_date >= t.hire_date + INTERVAL 1 YEAR) )

SELECT COUNT(*) /* check */ FROM employees e LEFT JOIN salaries s ON e.id = s.employee_id WHERE s.from_date >= (CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR) AND (s.to_date IS NULL OR s.to_date >= (CURDATE() - INTERVAL 1 YEAR))

SELECT * FROM customers c WHERE STR_TO_DATE('', '%') > 1

SELECT * FROM customers c WHERE c.id = (SELECT id FROM salaries s ORDER BY s.id DESC LIMIT 1)
SELECT * FROM customers c WHERE c.id > (SELECT id FROM salaries s LIMIT 1)

SELECT * FROM customers c WHERE FIND_IN_SET(c.id, (SELECT id FROM salaries s WHERE s.id > 1))
